title: Why the F**K do People Find the Need to say 'GGEZ'?
body: Seriously, I don't mind toxicity in game, thats fine, but when you've won a game and beaten a team there is nothing more unsportsmanlike then saying 'GGEZ' in chat, seriously, we're already pissed off enough that we've lost some lp, no need to make it worse by being a complete c*nt about. seriously.

replies.body: its actually a reportable offence

After playing for four or five years I can assure you some people don't get used to it, I usually don't mind, but when im on tilt and just wanna relax, don't play so well, and lose the game, and people find the need to be dickheads, It can be kind of annoying.
Majority of our playerbase agree's with you WEKT. They find it disrespectful and unsportsmanlike. If you think so as well, please report any player that says this at the end of a game.

While i agree thoroughly that saying 'GGEZ' is a stupid and disrespectful thing to say and those who say it are dumbasses. Is it really an offence worthy of Reporting? that someone could risk having their account suspended over?
i know its a stupid thing to say but if everyone reports people who say it you'll be reporting at least 2/3 people per game. 
Which means 2/3 people out of every game will be at risk of having their account suspended. which is a lot.

Its not like they're being racist or or homophobic or a nazi supporter or anything like that.
i agree that people shouldn't say it but if everyone gets reported for the little things all the time, it becomes a 'boy who cried wolf' situation and when the big things actually happen no one takes any notice because people are being reported left right and centre anyway.

The community gets to decide what is and isn't okay in this game. If a majority of our players agree that the phrase is unsportsmanlike and disrespectful then I think they should report the players that say it. If those player start receiving chat restrictions and reform cards telling them its not okay, but they keep saying it then they will continue up the escalation path - I.e. more chat restrictions, bans etc.

Of course it's not as bad as the other stuff you mentioned, but just because there is worse stuff out there doesn't mean this can't be dealt with too. 
http://i.imgur.com/kSXpCWW.jpg

There is a reason we have different types of punishments in place (chat restrictions 10 games, 20 games, 50 games, 100 games , time bans, permanent bans).

In my personal opinion sometimes I actually find gg ez "worse" than verbal abuse and racism (don't get me wrong these are REALLY BAD). If a player uses verbal abuse or racism in game I tend to think there's something wrong with them as a person, lack of empathy, childish tendencies etc and I can usually laugh it off just quietly to myself. But when someone says GG EZ, its like not bad enough for me to think there's something wrong with them like lack of empathy. When someone says this I think to myself, 

If it was a 20-minute game cause they snowballed for whatever reason (every lane of theirs won, afk etc) 
"Man there's nothing wrong with this person. They are actually just going out of their way to rub salt in the wound."

If it was a hard fought 40-50 minute game
"Man we fought so hard for that and this guy just had to be a dick about it at the end."

Doesn't even phase me the slighest tbh. If someone says "gg ez" after a 40-50 min game, i know it wasnt actually that easy. If it was a 20 min game, yeah it was ez but they still said gg. If you're getting salty over a simple phrase and not racism/verbal abuse, maybe you need to re-check priorities.
I'm offended by both tbh. I report both.

In this overly 'PC' world that this planet is becoming, we are becoming less and less tolerant of any slight discomfort, and people  can no-longer see the bigger picture.

i have 2 examples of how this spirals out of control:

1. 
When The Lego Movie came out there was a brief scene where the characters find themselves in a place called 'Middle Zealand' which was a medieval/castle type place with dragons etc. and was obviously a play on the words 'New Zealand' and 'Middle Earth' (middle earth being the lord of the rings realm that us kiwi's love to remind everyone was shot in NZ)
now a man called Winston Peters (who ranks very highly in the NZ government) took this mention of 'Middle Zealand' as a personal affront to our country calling it "a insult which likens NZ politics and financial situation to that of the middle ages!" and not only had the two directors of the movie fly down here to apologise but also tried to get Warner Bros to pay out 67 million dollars. It saddens me that a man like that who singlehandedly savaged our country's reputation and prevented all future fun references in movies about us from occurring again is running our country...

2.
There has been a lot of noise from fanatical feminists that there hasn't been very many Star Wars toys featuring Rey who is one of the main characters in the new Star Wars film, they say how unfair and sexist it is that Darth Vader who isn't even in the film (and is male) gets hundreds and hundreds of toy versions, while Rey (who is female) gets far far fewer. So much noise was created from this small group of feminists that Monopoly publicly apologised and promised to re-release all their Star Wars themed monopoly sets with her as a playable piece.


People get so caught up in their own little world where everything is against them that they lose sight of the fact that it doesn't actually matter. 

1.
It was a 'supposed to be fun' reference in a kids movie that never explicitly mentioned it was 'New Zealand' or 'Middle Earth' that they were referring to anyway.
Not worthy of making 2 (now famous) hollywood directors publicly apologise to a country as well as trying to extort millions from the film company on top of showing the world that NZ cant take a joke.

2. (minor star wars spoilers)
Rey is like most main characters, the boring old story recycled again and again: rags to riches, big fish trapped in a small pond, thinks they cant do anything meaningful but has a hidden power they don't know of, etc etc. (unlike Vader who paved the way for his character type at the time) Rey's looks are nothing special, she wears drab coloured sand clothing for the entirety of the film (looking no different to the torrent of sand coloured characters in the previous films), unlike Leia with her stereotypical hair and attitude Rey has no distinguishing features whatsoever, (unlike Vader who has the most memorable face in the history of sci-fi (if not every genre) films) her makeup makes her look plain and uninteresting, her voice is just ordinary (unlike Vader) apart from one fight scene she doesn't really do much in the scheme of things (and that fight was no different to most other fights in the series) (where as Vader was the whole reason of the first 6 films)
so of course its not a personal attack on the equality women by not making any toys of her.
of course the toy companies are going to make more Darth Vader toys than Rey toys, because more people want Darth Vader than Rey and so they will make more money by using their factories to produce his likeness instead of hers.
it has nothing at all to do with gender equality.
people cant see that bigger picture and instead focus on it being a personal attack on them.

My point is (shown by the ridiculousness of my examples) that we are missing the bigger picture here, in the very recent history we chained up and shipped over people who didn't share our skin tone (in ships that packed them together like sardines unable to move around while disease killed between 15 and 30% of them) to an alien country and whipped them raw while they did all our jobs for us, and now only a few decades later we are berating people for typing 4 letters on a recreational computer game? (the first 2 of which you are expected to say at the end of a game anyway)
lets look at the bigger picture here, its a computer game, not government, and there are always going to be dickheads in the world no mater what you do, and a few insecure adolescents rubbing proverbial salt in the proverbial wounds after beating you in a computer simulated game that you wont even remember them doing in 10 minutes time is the least of our worries.

i am by no means defending what they do, i think you're right its unbecoming and shows they are a bad winner (or loser) and isn't fair to the people who worked hard trying to keep their team in the game.

its true that the community gets to decide what is and isn't okay in the game, but because of our cushioned 1st world lifestyle, we have nothing real to complain about, and humans naturally want to complain about something (hell me writing this pointless post is proof of that) and because we have nothing major to complain about we do exactly what Winston Peters and the Feminist Zelots do and latch onto the tiny little problems in life and blow them out of proportion, we have lost the ability to see things in perspective, i can guarantee you that if we all worked 12 hours a day in the coal mines every day, no one would be complaining that there are too many Darth Vader toys on the shelves or that the kid halfway around the world wasn't secure enough in himself to say GG at the end of a game.

in reality It is no different to our rapidly deteriorating immune systems, if we take away all the major diseases that our bodies are supposed to fight they have nothing left to do except attack themselves. (which is what allergies are, and what these hospital superbugs do) 
and just like that isn't good for our bodies health, babying everyone to the point of not being able to type 4 letters at the end of a game is not good for peoples social health, or the social state of our society.

Anyway isn't Lol an american game and isn't 'freedom of speech' what the states are supposed to be all about?

No worries man, always happy to chat about whatever.

>  now only a few decades later we are berating people for typing 4 letters on a recreational computer game?

We aren't berating them at all, It's more like "thats not cool man, you should stop that". 

I don't think people are losing sight of the bigger picture, our players are taking a strong stance against verbal abuse and racism etc.

However that doesn't mean they can't ask for sportsmanlike games as well. I've played Chess competitions in primary and intermediate and have never had someone say anything along the lines of gg ez.

I've played baskeball throughout high school and univeristy, never had someone say anything along the lines of gg ez.

In fact for both competitions at the end of each game was usually hand shake with every player saying gg/maybe a compliment (nice 3's/defence), also thanking the ref. 

I feel like I should get the same experience on League of Legends, and a majority of games I do. Is it too much to ask for players to respect each other? 

You know like in all other competitive enviroments I have been in.

Each sport has its ups and downs, 

why you don't get 'GGEZ' In physical sports is 

1.  because people take more pride in accomplishing something in the physical sense rather than the virtual sense and so don't feel the need to put down others.
2.  because when you exercise, your body releases endorphins which act as a mental relaxant and anti-depressant, which again makes someone less uptight and likely to put down an opponent.
3.  certain personalities are attracted to physical sports more than others and these personalities happen to be ones that value teamwork and comradery.

Why you don't get it in chess is

1.  again it attracts a certain personality, one who is patient and calm.
2.  the sport has a (I'm hesitant to use the word aura, but the actual word escapes me so it will do as a substitute) about it that is globally accepted as an intellectual and 'proper' game, and so people don't misbehave. The same way James Bond doesn't go all red faced and run kicking and screaming at people because that scenario doesn't fit within the expected 'aura' that he is supped to adhere to.

Why you do get it in Lol (and other E sports) is 

1.  when in an immobile (often hunched over) state for a long time a kink in your neck blocks nerves and blood flow to the brain causing headaches which means the brain doesn't function as well and also leads to uncomfortableness and irritability. (which makes them more likely to put people down.)
2.  its no secret that lol can be extremely frustrating at times (even if youre winning) which again leads to irritability.
3.  (not saying everyone is like this) but because all you need to do is sit in a chair, it attracts the other kind of people, those who cant be fucked playing sports, don't have the patience for chess and other similar activities, also the younger demographic that are less mature and don't really understand how the sublties of good conduct. the lazier group also is more likely to pick up a mouse than a basket ball, and because they don't exercise are more prone to depression and their bodies hold more unspent tension than those who play sports.

obviously there are exceptions to all 3 sports, but because lol (unlike basketball) mashes you up with 10 different random people every game, statistically you get to see a lot more variety of people.

and lol isn't the only one, there is far more rage and snobbery in FPS games, I'm pretty sure tea-bagging in CoD would be just as bad as 'GGEZ' is in lol.

of course there are positives too, lol has much more variety in gameplay than BBall and chess, and to a lot of people is probably much more fun. You also have far fewer cheaters in lol (especially at a professional level) its hard to take steroids that improve your Syndra playing. and unless you're a CIA hacker, manipulating the code is out of the question. As a spectator sport its hard to beat, id rather watch lasers cutting down a katarina that tried and failed to flash away, than some guy dribbling a ball down the court in the same way he does every other game. 

But despite all that, there is no excuse for bad conduct in Lol, no matter how irritable you are, its a conscious decision to put down a fellow player and that can never be justified, but it also shouldn't be blown too far out of proportion IMO.

i personally have never reported anyone, i like to be as positive as possible in games and i detest those who purposely insult and degrade others, and will (unless i see it will only provoke the situation) try to defend the receiver of the insult.

> i personally have never reported anyone, i like to be as positive as possible in games and i detest those who purposely insult and degrade others, and will (unless i see it will only provoke the situation) try to defend the receiver of the insult.

That's really awesome that you do stand up and defend other players. But you can't be in every game, by reporting the players you detest, you can help protect hundreds more. Would you agree with that?

I would definitely agree with that, the reason that i don't is because i have no way of telling wether that person is naturally a bad person or wether they have had a bad day and just reached their boiling point for a 1 time only rage.

i know that i (i like to think) am non toxic, have on occasion after a really bad day given someone their what-for in the chat, (immediately regretting it) and i would hate to log on the next day and receive a "due to negative behaviour you have received a ban or a chat ban" because i know that isn't usually me, and i wouldn't wish the same on anyone else. 

Call me soft i guess.

My one of my good friends, i brought into the game a couple of years ago is one of the nicest people I've ever met and would go wayyy out of his way to help his friends, and has probably gifted more skins than anyone else i know, and is one of the most positive people in game. he has said 'GGEZ' once or twice, only to look 'cool' in front of his other friends, does he deserve a ban? i hope not.

if riot was really serious on it being a ban worthy offence, then they would have set up an automated system that just instabanned anyone who said 'GGEZ' in the last 30 seconds of a game. it wouldn't be hard (unlike swear words that can be used in different context it has only one use). But because that doesn't exist it must mean that riot also thinks that not all people who say it deserve a ban, which means that i may be reporting another person like my friend who doesn't deserve waking up the next morning with a punishment from the game he loves.

That's a really great point you bring up. It's definitely true that a lot of negativity in our game is due to players having a bad day (sometimes even multiple players having a bad day in the same game!).

Our system is designed to take into account the games you are reported in vs the games you arent reported in (i.e. kinda like on average how often do you get reported per 100 games.). So if you are only mildly negative and you are reported you aren't going to get punished if its like 1 in 100 games. You would have to be reported at a much higher rate to receive a punishment. 

This of course does not include the truly disgusting things some people say (death threats, racisim, homophobia etc). These things can be punished much faster thanks for our instant feedback system.

So I would urge you to report players for their behaviour in that single game, our system is designed to work this way and it takes into account more than just one game for the reasons you stated.

But this does lead me to another topic I personally find very interesting. 

> i know that i (i like to think) am non toxic, have on occasion after a really bad day given someone their what-for in the chat

I get that everyone has some bad days, whether thats real life, work, friends, relationships etc there are a tonne of out of League factors that can affect a players mood.

My question to you is, do you think you could on a bad day, Just not say anything at all rather than giving someone a bit of attitude in chat?
